p.content: This section considers qualitative adjectives, numbers and other quantifiers, articles, and demonstratives. The positions allowed for each of these elements within the nominal phrase will be dealt with in section

Qualitative adjectives express size, color, age, texture, form, or quality. One characteristic of this type of adjective is that more than one can modify a noun and in general the order of the adjectives can change (with a slight change in meaning due to the changes in scope of each adjective). For example,
versus
versus
This section is concerned with adjectives that modify nouns, in contrast to adjectives that acts as predicates. Predicate adjective constructions will be covered in section
Examples from
of the roots of qualitative adjectives which express size, color, age, texture, form or quality are given in the following chart. Each one may surface with the apropriate classifier attached.
Examples from
of qualitative adjectives which express size, color, age, texture, form or quality are given in the following chart:
Qualitative adjectives themselves may be modified. Some English examples are:
and
. Not all combinations of words work due to semantics and other considerations, but in general it seems that certain degree words and manner adverbs or manner adverb phrases can modify adjectives.
does not allow any degree words or manner adverbs to modify adjectives.
allows certain degree words to modify adjectives, but manner adverbs may not. The degree words occur

case.caseText: before
after
on either side (but not both sides) of
on either side or on both sides of
before or on both sides of
after or on both sides of
on both sides of

p.content: the adjective.

text.content: All of the degree words can occur on either side of the adjective.
There are restrictions as to which of the degree words can occur on each side of the adjective.

In
, there are affixes or clitics that attach to the qualitative adjective to intensify it. The degree affixes or clitics which can modify qualitative adjectives in
are:
Examples of qualitative adjectives with a degree affix or clitic attached are:
In
, reduplication is used to intensify the meaning of the qualitative adjective. Examples of qualitative adjectives with reduplication modifying or intensifying them are:

Numbers cannot be modified by the degree words like the qualitative adjectives and quantifiers can, though they usually occur in the same position as quantifiers. Cardinal numbers can, however, be modified by ordinal numbers and by
and
, as in
or
. Ordinal numbers and
and
can also modify nouns directly, as in
and
The basic forms for the cardinal numbers are given in the following chart. Each one may surface with the apropriate classifier attached.
The basic forms for the cardinal numbers are given in the following chart:
Larger cardinal numbers can be compounds which may be written as separate words, such as
or
p.langData: six thousand one hundred and thirty three
p.content: . Examples of compound numbers in
include:
Based on the position of the unit number and any conjunctions, cardinal numbers in
are

case.caseText: left-
right-

p.content: headed.
In
, ordinal numbers

case.caseText: are formed by adding an affix to the cardinal number.
are all independent syntactic words, distinct from the cardinal numbers.
may be formed by adding an affix to the cardinal number, but some forms are independent syntactic words.

p.content: The basic forms for the first ten ordinal numbers are given in the following chart. Each one may surface with the apropriate classifier attached.
The basic forms for the first ten ordinal numbers are given in the following chart:
When the ordinal numbers in
modify a cardinal number, as in
, they occur

case.caseText: before
after
on either side (but not both sides) of
on either side or on both sides of
before or on both sides of
after or on both sides of
on both sides of

p.content: the cardinal number.

text.content: All of the ordinal numbers can occur on either side of the cardinal number.
There are restrictions as to which of the ordinal numbers can occur on each side of the cardinal number.

p.content: examples of the use of ordinal numbers and the modifiers meaning “last” or “next” within a nominal phrase include:
Quantifiers can show up in various places in a nominal phrase. Most languages have three sets of quantifiers besides numbers:

li.content: , which modify the whole nominal phrase,
, which do not co-occur with any other modifers except adjectives,

p.content: Each type will be considered in turn.

section3.secTitle: Quantifiers which modify the whole nominal phrase

p.content: Quantifiers meaning
or
seem to be a category of their own. They usually occur first (or last) in a nominal phrase, in a position distinct from the other quantifiers but in the same place as degree words like
and
(which can also act as focus markers, to be discussed in section
) and words that mean the same as
(which can also co-occur with
), so we will refer to them as special degree words.
First, we will look at the positive forms which modify the whole nominal phrase, as in
and
In
, these are not expressed as separate words which modify the whole nominal phrase. Instead, they all attach to another word in the nominal phrase. The positive special degree elements are

case.caseText: phrasal proclitics which attach to the front of whatever word begins the nominal phrase.
phrasal enclitics which attach to the end of whatever word ends the nominal phrase.
phrasal clitics which attach either to the front of whatever word begins the nominal phrase or to the end of whatever word ends the nominal phrase.
prefixes which attach to the head noun of the nominal phrase.
suffixes which attach to the head noun of the nominal phrase.
either prefixes or suffixes which attach to the head noun of the nominal phrase.

p.content: In
, some are separate words but some of these are not expressed as separate words which modify the whole nominal phrase. Instead, some of the positive special degree elements are

case.caseText: phrasal proclitics which attach to the front of whatever word begins the nominal phrase.
phrasal enclitics which attach to the end of whatever word ends the nominal phrase.
phrasal clitics which attach either to the front of whatever word begins the nominal phrase or to the end of whatever word ends the nominal phrase.
prefixes which attach to the head noun of the nominal phrase.
suffixes which attach to the head noun of the nominal phrase.
either prefixes or suffixes which attach to the head noun of the nominal phrase.

after

section3.secTitle: Quantifiers which do not co-occur with Determiners

p.content: The second set includes quantifiers like
, and
, which do not allow any other articles, demonstratives or possessors in the nominal phrase.
Some English examples of nominal phrases including the positive quantifiers are
and
p.langData: almost every little girl that I see
p.content: . Ungrammatical examples such as
and
illustrate that these quantifiers do not co-occur with articles, demonstratives or possessors. Note that an example like
is grammatical, but this is a case of
as the head of the nominal phrase, with a partitive phrase
modifying it, which was covered in section
. Because they take the place of articles, demonstratives and possessors, we will treat these quantifiers as determiners which stand alone.
does not have a separate set of positive quantifiers which act as the only determiner in the nominal phrase. The positive notions of
and
are either like
above or like the quantifiers which may co-occur with articles, demonstratives and/or possessors to be treated in the next section.
has positive quantifiers which are written as separate words and act as the only determiner in the nominal phrase. They occur

case.caseText: before
after
on either side (but not both sides) of
on either side or on both sides of
before or on both sides of
after or on both sides of
on both sides of

p.content: the head noun.

text.content: All of the positive quantifier determiners can occur on either side of the noun.
There are restrictions as to which of these positive quantifier determiners can occur on each side of the noun.

p.content: examples of positive quantifier determiners in full nominal phrases include:
Turning to the negative quantifier determiner meaning
. Examples are
and
. Note that
contrasts with
from the previous section in that
cannot occur with articles, demonstratives or possessors, as illustrated by
and
does not have a separate negaitive quantifier which acts as the only determiner in the nominal phrase. The negative notion of
is like
in the previous section.
does not have a separate negaitive quantifier which acts as the only determiner in the nominal phrase. The negative notion of
is expressed by a clitic or affix that attaches to another word in the nominal phrase, like
in the previous section.
Just as there was not any way to express the negative special degree element
in the previous section, there is not any way to express
when it is modifying a nominal phrase in this language.
has negative quantifiers which are written as separate words and act as the only determiner in the nominal phrase. They occur

after
on either side (but not both sides) of

on both sides of

Other quantifiers, like
, and
, come in a different position in the nominal phrase. In English, this is after an article, demonstrative or possessor and before an adjective and noun, as in
. Further, these quantifiers can be modified by degree words such as
and
, as in
or
has the following quantifiers of this type. The forms shown in the chart are the roots; each one may surface with the apropriate classifier attached.
has the following quantifiers of this type:
does not have any degree words which modify the quantifiers.
has degree words which can modify the quantifiers. These degree words occur

case.caseText: before
after
on either side (but not both sides) of
on either side or on both sides of
before or on both sides of
after or on both sides of
on both sides of

p.content: the quantifier.

text.content: All of the degree words can occur on either side of the quantifier.
There are restrictions as to which of these degree words can occur on each side of the quantifier.

are shown here. Each one may surface with the apropriate classifier attached.

Examples showing the degree words modifying a quantifier are:
In English, the articles are
, and
. English demonstratives include
, and
. Some simple examples are:
p.langData: a book, an apple, the book, the books, this apple
p.content: and
Some languages only have one set, either articles or demonstratives. A few languages may not have either type expressed as separate words.

case.caseText: does not have either articles or demonstratives that are realized as separate words.
has only articles that are realized as separate words, no demonstratives.
has only demonstratives that are realized as separate words, no articles.
has both articles and demonstratives that are realized as separate words.

text.content: The

demonstratives
articles and demonstratives

text.content: are
not
marked for case.

p.content: In

case.caseText: both the definite and indefinite articles are overt words.
only the definite article is overt; indefinite nouns are unmarked.

p.content: Further, there

case.caseText: is only one set of articles which are used with both singular and plural nouns.
are separate forms of articles for singular and plural to agree with the noun.

are:
